column1: San Mateo ( SAN mə-TAY-oh; Spanish for '"Saint Matthew"') is a city in San Mateo County
column2: California
column3: about 20 miles (32 km) south of San Francisco
column4: and 31 miles (50 km) northwest of San Jose. San Mateo had an estimated 2019 population of 104
column5: 430.  It has a Mediterranean climate
column6: and is known for its rich history. The biggest economic contributors to the city include the Medical Center
column7: one of the local school districts
column8: and Sony's Sony Interactive Entertainment division. Finally
column9: being in the center of the San Francisco Bay Area
column10: it has many ways to travel beween the major cities of that area.

column1: Documented by Spanish colonists as part of the Rancho de las Pulgas (literally "Ranch of the Fleas") and the Rancho San Mateo
column2: the earliest history is held in the archives of Mission Dolores. In 1789
column3: the Spanish missionaries had named a Native American village along Laurel Creek as Los Laureles or the Laurels (Mission Dolores
column4: 1789).  At the time of Mexican Independence
column5: 30 native Californians were at San Mateo
column6: most likely from the Salson tribelet.Captain Fredrick W. Beechey in 1827 traveling with the hills on their right
column7: known in that part as the Sierra del Sur
column9: which passing over a small eminence
column10: opened out upon "a wide country of meadow land
column11: with clusters of fine oak free from underwood… It strongly resembled a nobleman's park: herds of cattle and horses were grazing upon the rich pasture
column13: startled at the approach of strangers
column14: bounded off to seek protection among the hills… This spot is named San Matheo
column15: and belongs to the mission of San Francisco."  An 1835 sketch map of the Rancho refers to the creek as Arroyo de Los Laureles. In the 21st century
column16: most of the laurels are gone
column18: Coyote Point was an early recorded feature of San Mateo.  Beginning in the 1850s

column20: a number of historically important mansions and buildings were constructed in San Mateo.A.P. Giannini

column22: lived here most of his life. His mansion

column2: Sun Water Station
column3: a stage station of the Butterfield Overland Mail route
column4: was established in San Mateo. It was located 9 miles south of Clarks Station in what is now San Bruno and 9 miles north of the next station at Redwood City.The Howard Estate was built in 1859 on the hill accessed by Crystal Springs Road. The Parrott Estate was erected in 1860 in the same area
column5: giving rise to two conflicting names for the hill
column6: Howard Hill and Parrot Hill. After use of the automobile changed traffic patterns
column7: neither historic name was commonly applied to that hill.  The Borel Estate was developed near Borel Creek in 1874. It has been redeveloped since the late 20th century for use as modern offices and shops. The property is managed and owned by Borel Place Associates and the Borel Estate Company.Hayward Park
column8: the 1880 American Queen Anne-style residence of Alvinza Hayward (often said to be "California's first millionaire" from his silver and banking fortunes)
column9: was built on an 800-acre (3.2 km2) estate in San Mateo which included a deer park and racetrack
column10: roughly bounded by present-day El Camino Real (on the west)
column12: B Street (on the east) and 16th Avenue (on the south). A smaller portion of the property and the mansion
column13: was converted into The Peninsula Hotel in 1908
column14: following Hayward's death in 1904. The Hotel burned down in a spectacular fire on 25 June 1920.

column2: Japanese immigrants came to San Mateo to work in the salt ponds and flower industry. Although Japanese-Americans only account for 2.2% of the population today
column3: they continue to be a major cultural influence and a draw for the rest of the region. The Eugene J. De Sabla Japanese Teahouse and Garden was established in 1894 at 70 De Sabla Road
column4: designed by Makoto Hagiwara
column5: designer of the Japanese garden in Golden Gate Park in San Francisco. He arranged for Japanese artisans to be brought to the United States primarily for its teahouse construction. The parcel was purchased in 1988 by San Francisco businessman Achille Paladini and wife Joan
column6: who have restored it. The garden features hundreds of varieties of plants and several rare trees. A large koi pond surrounds an island. The property was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1992.In December 1967
column8: then serving in Vietnam with Alpha Company
column10: 327th Infantry Regiment of the 101st Airborne Division wrote to his sister
column12: who was a resident of San Carlos working in San Mateo
column13: asking if San Mateo or San Francisco could adopt the Company
column14: saying that it would bring "the morale of the guys up as high as the clouds". San Mateo passed a resolution on March 4
column16: officially adopting Alpha Company and letters and gifts began arriving from the citizens of San Mateo. Joe would be killed in action on March 24
column18: less than three weeks after the resolution. Linda would travel to Vietnam to meet with the men of Alpha Company for Christmas in 1968 and deliver personalized medallions from the City of San Mateo. In 1972
column19: San Mateo requested and received permission to have Alpha Company visit the city when they left Vietnam
column20: later holding a parade in January 1972

column23: Lt. Stephen Patterson. The city expanded its support to the entire 1st Battalion in 1991

column1: The best-known natural area is Coyote Point Park
column2: a rock outcropped peninsula that juts out into the San Francisco Bay. The early Spanish navigators named it la punta de San Mateo. Crews of American cargo ships carrying grain in the bay renamed it Big Coyote. Sailors had a penchant for naming promontories at the edge of San Francisco Bay after the coyote; across the bay in Fremont are the Coyote Hills
column3: part of Coyote Hills Regional Park.  By the 1890s
column4: the shore area was developed as a popular beach called San Mateo Beach. In 1842
column5: the Spanish had named it playa de San Mateo. Today
column6: Coyote Point is home to CuriOdyssey
column7: formerly known as the Coyote Point Museum
column8: a major natural history museum and wildlife center in the state. The Peninsula Humane Society is also situated at Coyote Point.

column1: The variety of natural habitats includes mixed oak woodland
column2: riparian zones
column3: and bayland marshes. One endangered species
column4: the California clapper rail
column5: was sighted feeding on mudflats by the Third Avenue bridge in San Mateo.  The marsh areas are also likely habitat for the endangered salt marsh harvest mouse
column6: which inhabits the middle and high zones of salt and brackish marshes
column7: as well as for the endangered marsh plant

column2: whose name has been documented in 1870
column3: is a prominent landform between the forks of Laurel Creek. In the late 20th century
column4: this mixed oak woodland and chaparral habitat was a site of controversy related to proposals to develop a portion of the mountain for residential use. It has been preserved for use as park and open space area
column5: and is home to the endangered mission blue butterfly.

column1: San Mateo has a Mediterranean climate with warm
column2: dry summers and mild
column3: damp winters. The city is generally shielded from the Pacific Ocean by the Montara Mountain block of the Santa Cruz Mountains
column4: but two gaps in the mountains (the San Bruno Gap
column5: between Montara Mountain and San Bruno Mountain; and the Crystal Springs Gap
column6: near where State Route 92 meets State Route 35
column7: west of the College of San Mateo) can channel ocean weather
column8: resulting in gusty afternoon winds that bring fog toward San Mateo in the late afternoon through early morning in the summer.The National Weather Service maintained a cooperative weather station in San Mateo until 1978; records for the period show that January
column10: had an average maximum of 57.8 °F (14.3 °C) and an average minimum of 41.7 °F (5.4 °C)
column13: had an average maximum of 78.0 °F (25.6 °C) and an average minimum of 54.2 °F (12.3 °C). The record maximum temperature was 109 °F (43 °C) on June 14
column15: and the record minimum temperature was 25 °F (−4 °C) on January 5
column18: 1972. Annual precipitation averaged 18.77 inches (477 mm) of rainfall
column19: falling on an average of 60 days each year. The wettest year was 29.77 inches (756 mm) in 1973 and the driest year was 11.16 inches (283 mm) of rainfall in 1953. The most precipitation in one month was 12.59 inches (320 mm) of rainfall in December 1955 and the most precipitation in 24 hours was 3.72 inches (94 mm) of rainfall on December 23
column20: 1955. Based on comparison with the existing NWS office at San Francisco International Airport
column21: San Mateo is generally a few degrees warmer in summer than the airport and a few degrees cooler in winter
column22: while annual precipitation is almost the same at the airport and in San Mateo.  In recent years
column23: daily temperature reports for San Mateo from local weather observers have been published in the San Mateo Times and the San Francisco Chronicle.

column1: San Mateo is structured as a council-manager form of government. The City Council has five members elected every two years to staggered four-year terms.In the California State Legislature
column2: San Mateo is in the  13th Senate District
column3: represented by Democrat Jerry Hill
column4: and in the  22nd Assembly District
column5: represented by Democrat Kevin Mullin.In the United States House of Representatives
column6: San Mateo is in California's  14th congressional district
column7: represented by Democrat Jackie Speier.According to the California Secretary of State

column2: San Mateo's downtown core and neighborhoods east of El Camino Real are more populous and have a greater density than the neighborhoods to the west of El Camino Real
column3: where there is a lower population density.

column1: San Mateo has one of the larger
column2: well developed
column3: more prominent suburban downtowns in the San Francisco Bay Area.  It is located roughly between Tilton and 9th Avenues and Delaware Street and El Camino Real  The downtown core contains over 800 shops and restaurants
column4: many of them in historic buildings from the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The non-profit Downtown San Mateo Association (DSMA) works on behalf of downtown businesses to promote them and improve the downtown area. A historically influential area for the Japanese-American community
column5: the downtown is home to many Japanese restaurants and shops. A large
column6: modern 12-screen movie theatre complex gives the downtown a major entertainment option.  Central Park is considered to be San Mateo's signature park with tennis courts
column12: and a Japanese Tea Garden. San Mateo Caltrain station is situated downtown. The downtown also contains many large and small multi-story office buildings
column14: government buildings and Mills Medical Center
column15: making the area a busy employment center day and night.

column1: Hillsdale Shopping Center is a mall in San Mateo County
column2: with over 100 stores in the mall itself
column3: surrounded by many big box stores. The city of San Mateo has approved the construction of Cinépolis (luxury movie theater) and a Pinstripes bowling alley off El Camino Real. Sears is no longer in business and has been vacated for new businesses to occupy this space. Hillsdale Caltrain station is across El Camino Real.

column1: Bay Meadows Racetrack was a former horse racing track near Hillsdale Mall
column2: which closed down in 2008. It is being redeveloped into a large mixed-use development which will include hundreds of new residential units
column3: office space
column4: retail space and acres of parks including a town square. It started construction in 2013 and was completed in 2017. It is a significant amount of new construction given the limited space available for development in the city and the peninsula.

column1: Residents are zoned for schools in the San Mateo Foster City School District and San Mateo Union High School District. Elementary schools comprise Preschool
column3: Middle and Magnet schools. There is a private
column4: PreK-8 school: Saint Matthew's Episcopal Day School There are three public high schools: San Mateo
column5: Aragon
column6: and Hillsdale. There are also three private high schools: one all-male Catholic high school
column10: and the Nueva Upper School. There is the Carey School.

column1: The city is home to the College of San Mateo
column2: a community college. The campus of over 10
column3: 000 students is located on 153 acres in the western foothills of the city which offer a panoramic view of the San Francisco Bay. Other universities in the area include Notre Dame de Namur University
column4: a private Catholic university of 2
column5: 000 students in neighboring Belmont and Stanford University located about 12 miles to the south.

column1: The San Mateo Union High School District also hosts an adult school behind the campus of San Mateo High School.
The City of San Mateo operates three libraries within the city. The Main Library
column2: the Hillsdale Library
column3: and the Marina Library are all part of the Peninsula Library System. The Main Library located near Central Park in downtown opened in 2006 after residents passed a $30 million bond measure. Upon opening
column4: the three-story
column6: 000-square-foot building earned numerous design awards and was LEED-certified NC Gold. Floor-to-ceiling windows provide abundant natural light. The technologically advanced building is modeled after a retail bookstore.

column1: San Mateo maintains more than 15 parks throughout the city.
Central Park is considered to be the main one and hosts many community park functions that serve downtown residents. It has a Japanese tea garden
column2: a rose garden
column3: and a mini train. Beresford Park is another large park that offers bocce ball and a skate plaza. Martin Luther King Jr Park (37.574°N 122.325°W﻿ / 37.574; -122.325﻿ (Martin Luther King Jr Park)) and Joinville Park (37.568°N 122.293°W﻿ / 37.568; -122.293﻿ (Joinville Park)) offer swimming pools while Ryder Park boasts a water play structure. Parkside Aquatic Park located on Seal Slough (37.560°N 122.291°W﻿ / 37.560; -122.291﻿ (Parkside Aquatic Park)) has beach swimming and volleyball. Many of these parks have picnic areas with grills
column4: children's play areas
column5: basketball and tennis courts
column6: and baseball diamonds.Coyote Point Park is near the border with Burlingame and on the San Francisco Bay. It is a 670-acre regional county park known for its ideal location for windsurfing and sailing. It is also home to CuriOdyssey: a hands-on science museum and small native animal zoo.

column1: San Mateo is considered to be near the center of the San Francisco Bay Area about halfway between San Francisco and San Jose
column2: the region's two largest cities.  It is served by three major freeways including U.S. Route 101
column3: Interstate 280
column4: and State Route 92.  State Route 92 east of San Mateo traverses the San Francisco Bay as the San Mateo-Hayward Bridge to the city of Hayward on its eastern shore.

column1: San Mateo has a network of bikeways connecting major destinations in the city. In 2011
column2: the city approved a Bicycle Master Plan to establish bicycling goals
column3: identify gaps in the existing bikeways system
column4: and create a prioritized list of infrastructure improvement projects.

column1: SamTrans provides local bus service within the city of San Mateo as well as the entire county of San Mateo. AC Transit provides transbay bus service via the San Mateo Bridge to Alameda County. Caltrain provides commuter rail service on the San Francisco Peninsula between San Francisco and San Jose. Caltrain operates three stations within the city of San Mateo with stations at Hillsdale (serving the mall and surrounding area)
column2: Hayward Park (near Highway 92)
column3: and San Mateo (in downtown San Mateo). There are 41 northbound and 41 southbound trains with a stop in the city each weekday and 18 trains in both directions on weekends.  Extra southbound trains are run to accommodate passengers after San Francisco Giants games. See public transportation in San Mateo County for more details.

column1: San Mateo is located near three major airports including San Francisco International Airport seven miles to the north. Oakland International Airport and San Jose Mineta International Airport are also within a half an hour drive. San Carlos Airport is a general aviation airport located about six miles to the south.
Hospitals in San Mateo include San Mateo Medical Center
column2: an acute care facility operated by County of San Mateo. Cemeteries include Skylawn Memorial Park and St. John's Cemetery.

column1: The San Mateo Performing Arts Center
column2: located on the campus of San Mateo High School
column3: is one of the largest theatres on the peninsula outside of San Francisco. The College of San Mateo is also located in San Mateo and is home to radio station KCSM. The city is also home to the Bridgepointe and Hillsdale shopping centers. Bay Meadows horse-racing track was torn down in 2008.

column7: and artisans from the San Francisco Bay Area.
